moves.1. e4: I kick off with 1.e4, my favorite first move as it may leads to wild and tactical play.
moves.1... e5 2. f4: King's Gambit. I sacrifice a pawn for faster development.
moves.3... d6: Black responds with the Fisher Defense.
moves.4. d4: I grab the the center with my queen's pawn. I also attack Black's f4 pawn.
moves.4... Bg4: Black creates an annoying pin on my knight.
moves.5... Nd7 6. Bc4: I aim for f7, the weak square in Black's camp.
moves.6... Bxf3: ? This is a mistake, as it exchanges a piece that has moved twice for a piece that has moved only once. Such notions are essential in sharp game like these!
moves.7. Qxf3: Here is the consequence of Black's last move: I have 3 developed pieces for Black's knight. My queen also aims for the f7 square.
moves.7... Ne7: Another mistake. The king suffocates behind his pieces.
moves.8. O-O: !? I missed the following tactical shot: 8.Bxd6! f6 (8...cxd6 9.Bxf7#) 9.Qb3 Qb7, with a superior position. However, Castling here is not a mistake, as it doesn't compromise my game in any way.
moves.8... g6: ?? This is just too slow. Black completely ignores the threat on f7. Although mate is NOT forced from here, can you find the winning solution for white?
moves.10. Bg5+: ! Step 2: The discovery! Black has no viable answers to this attack.
moves.10... Ke6: ?? The best move was 10...Nf6 11.Qxf6+ Ke8 12.Qxh8. 10...Nf5 fails to 11.Bxg8. However, any king move leads to...
